Authors: Unfug F., Wagner U., Beck K.W., Pfeil J., Waldenmaier U., Celik O., Jaeschke J., Metzger J.
Title: Investigation of fuel spray propagation, combustion and soot formation/oxidation in a single cylinder medium speed diesel engine
Source title: ASME 2012 Internal Combustion Engine Division Fall Technical Conference, ICEF 2012
Affiliations: Karlsruhe Institute of Techn., Karlsruhe, Germany; MOT GmbH, Karlsruhe, Germany; MAN Diesel and Turbo SE, Augsburg, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Unfug, F., Karlsruhe Institute of Techn., Karlsruhe, Germany; Wagner, U., Karlsruhe Institute of Techn., Karlsruhe, Germany; Beck, K.W., MOT GmbH, Karlsruhe, Germany; Pfeil, J., MOT GmbH, Karlsruhe, Germany; Waldenmaier, U., MAN Diesel and Turbo SE, Augsburg, Germany; Celik, O., MAN Diesel and Turbo SE, Augsburg, Germany; Jaeschke, J., MAN Diesel and Turbo SE, Augsburg, Germany; Metzger, J., MAN Diesel and Turbo SE, Augsburg, Germany
Abstract: To fulfil strict emission regulations and the need for higher efficiency of future Diesel engines require an optimized combustion process. Optical investigations represent a powerful tool for getting a better understanding of the ongoing processes. For medium speed Diesel engines, optical investigations are relatively rare or not available. The "Institut für Kolbenmaschinen" (IFKM) and MAN Diesel & Turbo SE performed extensive optical in-situ investigations of the injection and combustion process of a MAN 32/44 CR single cylinder medium speed Diesel engine that provide previously unavailable insights into the ongoing processes. The optical investigations aimed on fuel spray visualization, high-speed soot luminescence measurement and two colour pyrometry applied for five combustion chamber regions. To apply the optical measurement techniques, two optical accesses were designed. Access no. 1 is placed near the cylinder liner. Access no. 2 is located close to the injector in a 46° angle to the cylinder vertical axis. An insert was used which consists of an illumination port and a visualization endoscope. Additionally some special nozzle designs were used beside the standard nozzle, which have one separated nozzle hole. This enables a simultaneous view from both optical accesses on the same flame cone. For Mie-Scattering investigation a pulsed Nd:YAG-Laser with 532 nm wavelength was used for illumination and a CCDcamera with an upstream 532 nm optical filter was used for visualization. This combination allows observing the liquid fuel distribution even after start of combustion. Penetration depth of liquid fuel spray was analysed for different swirl numbers, intake manifold pressures, injection timings and injection pressures. High-speed flame visualization was done by two CMOS cameras which were mounted at two different optical accesses with view on the same flame cone. Due to this application a simultaneous measurement of the flame distribution of two different views was possible. This enables a 3-dimensional investigation of the flame propagation process. In addition, the advanced two colour pyrometry was applied for five different regions of the same flame cone. Due to a calibration after each measurement the absolute radiant flux can be calculated and thus the absolute temperature and soot concentration. With this procedure it was possible to give a real temperature and soot concentration distribution of the flame cone. To provide more detailed information about the combustion process, selected engine operation points were simulated with a modified version of the CFD code KIVA3v-Release2 at the IFKM. The simulated results were compared to the measured data. Copyright © 2012 by ASME.
Index Keywords: Emission regulation; Fuel spray propagation; In-situ investigations; Luminescence measurements; Medium speed diesel engine; Optical investigation; Optical measurement techniques; Simultaneous measurement; CMOS integrated circuits; Combustion; Combustion chambers; Computational fluid dynamics; In situ combustion; Liquid fuels; Neodymium lasers; Nozzles; Optical data processing; Pyrometers; Pyrometry; Soot; Visualization; Diesel engines

Authors: Uljanic B., Pfajfar T., Papic I., Blažic B.
Title: Voltage control in distribution networks with distributed generation [Regulacija napetosti v distribucijskih omrežjih s pomocjo razpršenih virov]
Affiliations: University of Ljubljana, Faculty of Electrical Engineering, Tržaška 25, 1000 Ljubljana, Slovenia; Reinhausen 2e Ltd., Tehnološki park 24, 1000 Ljubljana, Slovenia
Authors with affiliations: Uljanic, B., University of Ljubljana, Faculty of Electrical Engineering, Tržaška 25, 1000 Ljubljana, Slovenia; Pfajfar, T., Reinhausen 2e Ltd., Tehnološki park 24, 1000 Ljubljana, Slovenia; Papic, I., University of Ljubljana, Faculty of Electrical Engineering, Tržaška 25, 1000 Ljubljana, Slovenia; Blažic, B., University of Ljubljana, Faculty of Electrical Engineering, Tržaška 25, 1000 Ljubljana, Slovenia
Abstract: One of the goals of the European energy policy is to reach the ''20-20-20'' targets which by 2020 foresee a 20 % increase in energy efficiency, a 20 % reduction in CO2 gas emissions and a 20 % increase in power production from renewable energy sources. As a result there will probably be a substantial increase in the share of renewable (and dispersed) energy sources in final consumption and accelerated investment in renewable energy sources and their integration into the electric power system. The nominal power of distributed generation (DG) is relatively small and it is not concentrated in just one part of the network but throughout it. Due to their limited power, DG sources are connected to the distribution network. Their production depends on a number of factors and is difficult to predict. Inclusion of a large share of DG in the distribution network was not planned when the network was designed. As DG affects network operation, some difficulties may be expected. One of the first ones is most likely to be violation of the set limits because of the changes in network voltage. The paper is structured as follows. First, changes taking place in power network due to DG connection are described. To follow are a description of the impact of DG on the network voltage states and analytical determination of its impact on the voltage. Possible voltage control strategies with DG are shown by means of network simulations. The paper end by comparing losses incurred in different voltage-control regimes.
Author Keywords: Distributed generation; Network losses; Voltage control; Voltage profile
Index Keywords: Analytical determination; Control strategies; Energy source; European energy policy; Network loss; Network operations; Network simulation; Power networks; Power production; Renewable energy source; Voltage profile; Carbon dioxide; Distributed power generation; Electric power systems; Energy efficiency; Energy policy; Gas emissions; Investments; Natural resources; Renewable energy resources; Voltage control; Computer simulation

Authors: Udu-gama N., Thomalla F., Carnegie M.
Title: Enhancing disaster resilience: The role of community early warning systems
Source title: Proceedings of the 4th International Disaster and Risk Conference: Integrative Risk Management in a Changing World - Pathways to a Resilient Society, IDRC Davos 2012
Affiliations: Macquarie University, Sydney, Australia
Authors with affiliations: Udu-gama, N., Macquarie University, Sydney, Australia; Thomalla, F., Macquarie University, Sydney, Australia; Carnegie, M., Macquarie University, Sydney, Australia
Abstract: Many communities are exposed to a growing number of environmental risks due to natural hazards, population pressures, misuse of natural resources, poor planning, and climate change. Early warning systems (EWS) are increasingly understood as an effective disaster risk reduction (DRR) mechanism that can support communities at-risk in minimizing the adverse effects of natural hazards upon their lives and livelihoods. Despite this insight, many EWS remain disjointed, ineffective and unsustainable since few have genuinely managed to address multiple community vulnerabilities and priorities, and to incorporate local hazard knowledge and skills with sustainable technology, financial and human resources. As climate-related hazards have increased in magnitude, frequency and severity in many parts of the world, so has the discourse on community EWS (CEWS) evolved. This extended abstract gives evidence as to why a CEWS is an essential element of DRR to build community resilience. It also presents arguments on why social capital and partnerships are important to consider when designing and implementing CEWS, and how CEWS fit within the integrative risk management framework.
Author Keywords: Community; Early warning system; Partnership; Resilience; Social capital
Index Keywords: Climate change; Disasters; Hazards; Risk management; Community; Early Warning System; Partnership; Resilience; Social capitals; Alarm systems
